description: The noun is derived from in +‎ road (“(obsolete) act of riding on horseback; hostile ride against a particular area, raid”).
The verb is derived from the noun.

entries.meaning: (military, also figuratively) An advance into enemy territory, an attempted invasion; an encroachment, an incursion.
examples: Synonyms: foray, inbreak, inbreaking, infall, raid

entries.meaning: (figuratively, usually in the plural) Often followed by in, into, or on: initial progress made toward accomplishing a goal or solving a problem.
examples: Three weeks into it, I am finally beginning to make inroads on this project.

verbs.description: inroad (third-person singular simple present inroads, present participle inroading, simple past and past participle inroaded)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, archaic) To make advances or incursions.
(transitive, obsolete) To make an inroad into (something).
